section.heading: Alternative Disciplinary Sanctions and Informal Disposition Sanctions.

para.text: Privilege Suspension.

Suspension of a defendant’s Department or facility inmate privileges may be imposed as a sanction for an inmate rule violation of which the defendant was found guilty or as part of an offer of informal disposition.
Suspension of Department or facility inmate privileges is based on the judgment of the hearing officer or staff offering the informal disposition.
The hearing officer or staff may suspend a defendant’s Department or facility inmate privileges as a sanction for the period specified under this regulation.
Staff may:
Only impose a sanction as part of an informal disposition agreed to by the defendant; and
Not impose a sanction while the defendant is pending a disciplinary proceeding.
A defendant may be placed on administrative segregation pending a disciplinary proceeding for safety or security reasons.
Informal Disposition or Alternative Disciplinary Sanctions.
An informal disposition sanction or alternative disciplinary sanction is separate and distinct from the revoking of earned credits and disciplinary segregation as a sanction.
The hearing officer or staff when offering a defendant an informal disposition shall include a sanction from the sanctions listed under §C of this regulation.
The hearing officer may impose an alternative disciplinary sanction listed under §D of this regulation for the defendant’s inmate rule violation resulting in a guilty finding.
An alternative disciplinary sanction may be imposed independently of or in conjunction with:
Another alternative disciplinary sanction;
Revoking earned credits; or
Disciplinary segregation.
Informal Disposition Sanctions. The following may be imposed as a sanction under an informal disposition:
Reprimand;
Sanitation assignment for a specific period up to but not to exceed 15 calendar days;
Restitution;
Suspension of any of the following privileges:

Radio, compact disc or tape player, digital music player, video game player, television, telephone, or commissary, privileges excluding personal hygiene and legal correspondence items, for a specified period up to but not to exceed 30 calendar days;
Catalog privileges for a specified period up to but not to exceed 180 calendar days;
Visitation privileges, except legal and clergy, for a specified period up to but not to exceed 30 calendar days;
A specified Department or facility inmate privilege not included in this regulation for a specified period up to but not to exceed 30 calendar days; or
Cell restriction for a specified period up to but not to exceed 15 calendar days.
The following may be imposed as a sanction under an alternative disciplinary sanction:
Reprimand;
Sanitation assignment for a specified period up to but not to exceed 30 calendar days;
Restitution;
Suspension of any of the following privileges:

Radio, compact disc or tape player, television, telephone, or commissary, excluding personal hygiene and legal correspondence items, privileges for a specified period up to but not to exceed 60 calendar days;
Catalog privileges for a specified period up to but not to exceed 365 calendar days;
Visitation privilege, except legal and clergy, for a specified period up to but not to exceed 60 calendar days; or
A Department or facility privilege not included in this regulation for a specified period up to 60 calendar days;
Cell restriction for a specified period up to but not to exceed 30 calendar days; or
Restriction of visitation privilege, except for legal and clergy visitation, to immediate family members for a specified period of up to 180 calendar days.
Cell restriction under this regulation:

Shall include a requirement that the defendant is restricted to a designated location and prohibited from participation in all Department or facility inmate privileges and activities to include recreation and commissary; but
May not prohibit the defendant from participation in:
Work, program, or school assignments;
Meals as scheduled by the facility;
Shower periods as scheduled and permitted by the facility staff for an inmate designated cell restriction status;
Visitation periods as scheduled and permitted by the facility’s rules;
Facility passes as scheduled and permitted by facility staff;
A religious service as scheduled and permitted by the facility’s rules;
Case management, medical, or psychological appointments as scheduled and permitted by facility staff; and
Commissary purchases of personal hygiene and legal correspondence items permitted by the facility’s rules.
Cell restriction and segregation may not be served or imposed consecutively.

section.heading: Disciplinary Proceeding Procedures — Post Disciplinary Proceeding Phase — The Hearing Officer’s Decision and Case Record.

para.text: Hearing Officer’s Decision.
The hearing officer, at the conclusion of a defendant’s disciplinary proceeding shall prepare a written decision documenting the decision rendered.
The hearing officer’s written decision regarding the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding shall include:
Preliminary matters raised by hearing participants during the preliminary hearing;

A summary of the evidence and testimony presented during the case presentation by the defendant, if applicable the defendant’s representative, if applicable facility representative, or facility staff;
A summary of the evidence found credible and reliable;
The findings of fact made by the hearing officer;
The disposition of each inmate rule violation charged;
The sanction and period of the sanction imposed for each inmate rule violation resulting in a guilty finding; and
If applicable, documentation for the informal resolution accepted by the defendant.

Service of the Decision. Upon receipt of the hearing officer’s written decision, facility staff shall serve the defendant with a copy of the hearing officer’s decision within 3 business days following the date of the hearing officer’s decision.

The facility representative, if designated, or designated facility staff shall follow the process established by the managing official, or a designee, for the defendant’s housing facility for distribution of the hearing officer’s decision that includes:
Advising appropriate staff of the hearing officer’s decision and sanctions, if applicable; and
Returning documents, records, and physical evidence regarding the defendant’s concluded disciplinary proceeding to the designated file or storage location.
Inmate Case Record.
Staff shall be responsible for maintaining and documenting a case record of the defendant’s disciplinary history.
The defendant’s case record shall include the following information:
A guilty decision;
A not guilty decision;
A Not Competent decision;
An informal resolution;
A dismissal of the inmate rule violation charged;
The facility’s copy of the Notice of Inmate Rule Violation form and Notice of Inmate Disciplinary Hearing form;
The written record of the disciplinary proceeding; and
An attachment or other evidence that was considered at the disciplinary proceeding, except if the items are determined to be security sensitive or confidential as provided in this chapter.
Except for security sensitive information, and subject to Correctional Services Article, §3-602, Annotated Code of Maryland, a defendant’s case record may be reviewed by:
Facility staff or Department staff;
The Department Intelligence and Investigative Division;
A law enforcement agency;
An attorney or an individual authorized in writing by the defendant;
Staff of the Parole Commission or the Division of Parole and Probation;
An individual or agency authorized by the Secretary, or a designee, or statute or as otherwise provided by law;
Staff of the Office of the Attorney General;
Staff of the Inmate Grievance Office;
Staff of the Office of Administrative Hearings; and
Staff of a State’s Attorney’s Office.
Security sensitive information may only be released with authorization from the Secretary, or a designee, to:
Department staff on a need to know basis;
The Department’s Intelligence and Investigative Division;
A law enforcement agency;
An individual or agency authorized by the Secretary, or a designee, or as otherwise provided by law;
Staff of a State’s Attorney’s Office; and
Staff of the Office of the Attorney General.
Staff shall ensure that the defendant’s case record is maintained under the requirements of the Correctional Services Article for the retention of inmate case record information.
Audio Record.
The audio recording of the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding is a record of the Department that is for the:
Internal operations and administrative functions of the Department; and
Administration and management of the Department’s business.
An audio record may not be considered a right, interest, benefit, or an entitlement for the defendant.

Staff shall ensure that the audio record of a defendant’s disciplinary proceeding is maintained under the requirements of the Correctional Services Article for the retention of inmate case record information.

A copy of an audio record may be requested and provided as required under COMAR 12.11.02 Public Information Requests, but will only be released if permitted under Correctional Services Article, §3-602, Annotated Code of Maryland.

An audio recording is not considered to be part of the administrative record of a disciplinary proceeding that is forwarded to the Inmate Grievance Office or the Office of Administrative Hearings in an inmate grievance.
A fee in the amount of $5 for the cost of copying an audio record shall be charged to the interested party requesting a copy of an audio recording of a disciplinary proceeding.

section.heading: Disciplinary Proceeding Procedures — Post Disciplinary Proceeding Phase — Appeal of the Hearing Officer’s Decision or Sanction.

para.text: Appeal by the Defendant.
A defendant may only appeal the:
Sufficiency of the evidence presented as part of the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding;
Interpretation of the law, rules, policy, procedures, or regulations applicable to the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding; or
Sanction imposed as a result of the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding.

A defendant shall file an appeal in writing with the managing official of the facility where the defendant is housed within 15 calendar days of the date the defendant received the hearing officer’s decision.

If the defendant fails to file a written appeal with the managing official or the managing official does not receive the defendant’s appeal within the 15 calendar days of the date of the hearing officer’s decision, the defendant is:
Considered to have waived the opportunity to appeal under this regulation; and
Not considered to have exhausted administrative remedies available to the defendant.

If the defendant is transferred to another facility other than the facility where the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding occurred within the 15 calendar days, the defendant may file the appeal with the managing official of either facility.
The managing official of the sending facility shall forward the appeal to the facility that receives the defendant.
The defendant shall give notice of the transfer and appeal to the managing official of the receiving facility.
Appeal by the Facility.
If designated, a facility representative, or in the absence of a representative, facility staff may appeal:
The hearing officer’s decision; and
If applicable, sanctions imposed.
An appeal shall be in writing and delivered to the managing official within 5 calendar days of the date of the hearing officer’s decision.
Appeal to the Inmate Grievance Office. A defendant may appeal the managing official’s decision to the Inmate Grievance Office as provided under COMAR 12.07.01.05 and 12.07.01.08.
Appeal — Guilty Plea.

If a defendant entered a guilty plea to an inmate rule violation charged and the hearing officer accepted and entered the plea into the record of the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding, the defendant may file an appeal based on only the following claims:
The process or procedures by which the defendant entered the guilty plea regarding the inmate rule violation charged was in error or the guilty plea was procedurally not permitted; and
If imposed, the hearing officer’s sanction was in error or procedurally not permitted.
A defendant filing an appeal of a guilty plea may not raise a claim that:
The hearing officer’s decision was arbitrary or capricious, clearly erroneous, or not based on substantial evidence;
The hearing officer relied on evidence that was insufficient or considered in error;
There was a denial or violation of a due process, statutory, time, or procedure requirement applicable to this chapter; or
There was a denial by staff or the hearing officer of a representative, a witness, or evidence requested.
Appeal — Waiver of Appearance.

If a defendant waived the defendant’s appearance before a hearing officer and in the defendant’s absence the hearing officer proceeded with the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding and found the defendant guilty of the inmate rule violation charged, the defendant may file an appeal that is limited to a claim that the:
Process by which the hearing officer concluded that the defendant waived an appearance was in error;
Hearing officer’s decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged for which the defendant was found guilty was arbitrary, capricious, or clearly erroneous;
Hearing officer’s decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged for which the defendant was found guilty relied on evidence that was in error, insufficient, or procedurally not permitted; or
Sanction imposed regarding the inmate rule violation charged for which the defendant was found guilty was in error or procedurally not permitted.
A defendant who waived an appearance before the hearing officer may not raise a claim that there was a:
Denial of a due process, statutory, time, or procedure requirement applicable to this chapter; or
Denial of a representative, a witness, or evidence regarding the disciplinary proceeding.
The time period for a defendant to file an appeal expires at the end of the 15th calendar day after the date the defendant was served with the hearing officer’s decision.

section.heading: Disciplinary Proceeding Procedures — Post Disciplinary Proceedings Phase — Managing Official’s Review.

para.text: Review by the Managing Official.
The managing official, or a designee, shall conduct a review of the defendant’s disciplinary proceeding.
The managing official may assign a designee to conduct the required review.
The managing official, or designee, shall review a defendant’s disciplinary proceeding before the hearing officer even if the ultimate disposition is an informal resolution.
The informal resolution offered by staff and accepted by the defendant are not required to be reviewed.
A managing official’s, or a designee’s, review is a review on the record and not a de novo or new hearing.
The managing official may not:
Reconsider the evidence in the record of the disciplinary proceeding;
Substitute the managing official’s, or a designee’s, judgment for that of the hearing officer’s or make de novo or new fact findings as to the inmate rule violation charged; and
Render a de novo or new decision in lieu of the decision by the hearing officer.
The managing official, or a designee, shall document the review in the written record of the disciplinary proceeding.

The managing official, or a designee, shall complete the review of the hearing officer’s decision and sanction, if imposed, regarding the inmate rule violation charged within 30 calendar days of the date the defendant received the hearing officer’s decision, but after the 15 calendar day time period for the filing of an appeal by the defendant has elapsed.
The managing official, or a designee, may conduct an immediate review of the hearing officer’s decision without waiting for the expiration of the defendant’s appeal period:
When the disposition of one or more of the inmate rule violations is:
A dismissal;
A Not Guilty finding;
A finding that the defendant is or was Not Competent; or
An informal resolution accepted by the defendant; or
The managing official, or a designee, reduces a sanction imposed by the hearing officer.
The managing official, or a designee, may remand the hearing officer’s decision to the hearing officer for written clarification by the hearing officer of the decision or sanction regarding the:
Disciplinary proceeding procedures;
Evidence weighed and considered;
Findings of fact;
Decision as to the inmate rule violation charged; and
Sanction, if imposed.
The time and procedure requirements for the managing official’s review:
Shall be suspended pending the managing official’s, or a designee’s, remand; and
May not resume until the managing official, or a designee, receives the hearing officer’s written response.
Authority and Action of the Managing Official.
A managing official, or a designee, conducting the review of the hearing officer’s decision shall:

Review the record of the disciplinary proceeding and determine from that record if a reasonable individual could have reached the decision rendered by the hearing officer based on the evidence presented at the disciplinary proceeding;
Consider an alleged time or procedural violation under this chapter, when raised in an appeal by the defendant, facility representative or facility staff; and
Determine if the sanctions imposed were in compliance with the requirements of this chapter.

The managing official, or a designee, when conducting the review of the hearing officer’s decision regarding an inmate rule violation resulting in a guilty finding and, if imposed, the sanction, may, without explanation:
Affirm the hearing officer’s decision and, if imposed the sanction;

Vacate the guilty finding and the sanction imposed regardless of the category of the inmate rule violation charged or procedural requirement of this chapter, and enter an incident report in the defendant’s case record as the disposition for the inmate rule violation charged;
Vacate the guilty finding and the sanction imposed and enter a Not Guilty disposition in the defendant’s case record for the inmate rule violation charged;
Vacate the guilty finding and the sanction imposed and enter a Not Competent disposition in the defendant’s case record for the inmate rule violation charged; or
Affirm the hearing officer’s decision, but elect to modify the sanction imposed for the inmate rule violation resulting in a guilty finding by:

Reducing the sanction period imposed by the hearing officer regardless of whether the reduced sanction is in compliance with or below the minimum sanction or sanction period required by a regulation of this chapter; or
Reducing an informal disposition with sanction to an incident report with no sanction.
The managing official, or a designee, may not increase the sanctions imposed by the hearing officer.

The managing official, or a designee, may appeal the hearing officer’s decision to the Secretary, or a designee, and request the Secretary, or a designee, to reverse the hearing officer’s decision and remand the inmate rule violation charged for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding when the managing official, or a designee, concludes the hearing officer’s decision was erroneous due to one or more of the following circumstances:
An arbitrary or capricious decision;
A clearly erroneous decision;
An erroneous interpretation of a policy, time requirement, or procedure;
The decision relied on evidence alleged or found to be fraudulent or a misrepresented;
The decision was rendered without consideration of evidence that was either presented or not presented at the defendant’s disciplinary hearing;
The sanction was not in compliance with minimum requirements of regulations in this chapter; or
A disposition of Not Competent was entered and there is new evidence that the defendant is competent to participate in the disciplinary proceeding or was competent at the time of the offense.
The managing official’s, or a designee’s, recommendation for reversal and new disciplinary proceeding shall include the reason for the appeal.
The time period and procedure requirements for the managing official’s, or a designee’s, review under this regulation shall:
Be suspended pending the managing official’s, or a designee’s, appeal to the Secretary, or a designee; and
Resume on the date the Secretary’s, or a designee’s, written decision regarding the managing official’s, or a designee’s, appeal is received by the managing official, or a designee.
Notification of the Managing Official’s Review.

Staff shall serve the documentation of a completed managing official’s, or a designee’s, review on the defendant within 30 calendar days of the date the defendant was previously served the hearing officer’s decision.
If the defendant does not receive the managing official’s, or a designee’s, review under the 30 calendar day time requirement the:
Review process is considered to be complete; and
Hearing officer’s decision and sanction, if imposed, is affirmed.

section.heading: Disciplinary Proceeding Procedures — Post Disciplinary Proceedings Phase — Remanding the Inmate Rule Violation Charged.

para.text: Only the Secretary, or a designee, or a court of proper jurisdiction may disturb the decision concerning an inmate rule violation charged and:
Reverse the decision of the hearing officer regarding the inmate rule violation charged: and
Remand the case for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding under this regulation.

The managing official, or a designee, when conducting a review of the hearing officer’s decision or a decision previously reviewed by a managing official, or a designee, may, without regard for a procedure or time requirement under this chapter:

Appeal the hearing officer’s decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged to the Secretary, or a designee, regardless of the date of the decision or if previously reviewed by a managing official; and
Request the Secretary, or a designee, to reverse the hearing officer’s decision and remand the inmate rule violation charged for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding under this regulation.

The Secretary, or a designee, upon receipt and review of the managing official’s, or a designee’s, appeal may approve or disapprove the managing official’s, or a designee’s, recommendation to reverse the hearing officer’s decision and remand the case for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding under this regulation:
If the Secretary, or a designee, disapproves the managing official’s, or a designee’s, recommendation, the:
Secretary, or a designee, shall notify the managing official, or a designee, that the hearing officer’s decision is affirmed; and
Managing official, or a designee, shall notify the defendant of the Secretary’s, or a designee’s, decision.
If the Secretary, or designee, approves the managing official’s, or a designee’s, recommendation, the:
Hearing officer’s decision is considered to be reversed; and
Inmate rule violation charged is to be scheduled for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding.
When the disciplinary proceeding is remanded for a de novo disciplinary proceeding, the managing official, or a designee, shall:
Notify the defendant of the Secretary’s, or a designee’s, decision;
Ensure that the defendant is scheduled for a remanded disciplinary proceeding;
Notify staff that the disciplinary proceeding is heard de novo unless ordered otherwise by the Secretary, or a designee; and
Ensure that the remanded disciplinary proceeding is not heard by the original hearing officer of record unless otherwise ordered by the Secretary, or a designee.
Rehearing Procedure.

Within 7 business days of the managing official’s, or a designee’s, notification of a Secretary’s order or order of a court that the inmate rule violation charged was remanded for a de novo or a new disciplinary proceeding under this regulation, staff shall:
Provide the defendant with a copy of the Notice of Inmate Rule Violation form and Notice of Inmate Disciplinary Hearing form regarding the remanded inmate rule violation charged;
Provide the defendant the opportunity to request representation, a witness, or evidence at service; and
Schedule the defendant for a disciplinary proceeding.

Except for the 7 business day time frame for service of the remand order on the defendant, the time and procedure requirements of this chapter shall govern the disciplinary proceeding and post disciplinary proceeding phases conducted as a remanded hearing in accordance with this regulation.
The managing official, or a designee, may appeal the hearing officer’s decision of the remanded disciplinary proceeding in accordance with the procedures under this chapter.
The defendant may appeal the hearing officer’s decision of the remanded disciplinary proceeding in accordance with the procedures under this chapter.

section.heading: Disciplinary Proceeding Procedures — Post Disciplinary Proceedings Phase — Review by the Secretary.

para.text: The Secretary, or a designee, has the:
Authority and discretion to modify, suspend, or terminate the inmate disciplinary process consistent with due process; and
Final authority to interpret the time and procedure requirements of the inmate disciplinary process.

The Secretary, or a designee, without regard for a time or procedure requirement established under this chapter, may review a disciplinary proceeding or hearing officer’s decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged.

The Secretary, or a designee, without regard for a time or procedure requirement established under this chapter, may take an action regarding a disciplinary proceeding or hearing officer’s or staff’s decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged that includes, but is not limited to:
Remanding the inmate rule violation charged for:
A de novo or new inmate disciplinary proceeding; or
Other action permitted under this chapter;
Modifying or vacating a sanction imposed regarding the inmate rule violation found guilty or an informal disposition;
Reversing a decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged found guilty, not guilty, dismissed, not competent, or due to an informal resolution;
Reducing a decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged or an informal disposition to an incident report; or
Vacating the decision regarding the inmate rule violation charged found guilty, not guilty, dismissed, not competent, or reduction to an informal resolution.

section.heading: Video Conferencing.
section.text: The Department may, for the purposes of the inmate disciplinary process, use video conferencing or other electronic media or technology.
